poem:
Garden Reverie  

I dream of a stone table,  
moss-kissed and ancient,  
beneath a whispering tree.  
Here, flower pots gather  
like old friends,  
each spilling secrets  
into the gravel tapestry,  
while summer drapes  
its languid arm  
around our shoulders,  
and shade mingles  
with our laughter,  
a fantasy of stillness,  
rooted yet alive.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "My latest garden fantasy? I long for this table because, in the similarly fantastical small urban garden in my head, it is the answer to a number of problems. In the summer it hosts languorous".
